user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex:
```c
int32 OS_Posix_BinSemAcquireMutex(pthread_mutex_t *mut)
{
    struct timespec timeout;

    if (clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    timeout.tv_sec += OS_POSIX_BINSEM_MAX_WAIT_SECONDS;

    if (pthread_mutex_timedlock(mut, &timeout) != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, &timeout) != 0)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: clock_gettime has prototype int clock_gettime(clockid_t, struct timespec *), and it writes into the supplied struct timespec. Passing &timeout (a non-const object) to a function that modifies it is correct; the pointer cannot be const-qualified in this case. A concrete violation scenario would be if the callee did not modify the object but its parameter was declared without const — e.g. a function that only reads a timespec but has prototype void read_time(struct timespec *tp) instead of void read_time(const struct timespec *tp); that would violate Rule 8.13.
